awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Impact of Flow-Induced Chain Alignment in Melt-Processed Complementary Semiconducting Polymer Blends
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: 

Semiconducting polymers are a special class of macromolecules that can conduct electrical currents and absorb or emit light. These polymers are used in a wide range of electronic devices, including light-emitting diodes, solar cells, transistors, and many others.  This CAREER project is concerned with melt-processable semiconducting polymers, a departure from the current focus of solution-processed polymers (which usually involve toxic and environmentally harmful solvents for processing). Specifically, the proposal research is to explore, understand, and optimize flow-induced orientation in melt-processed semiconducting polymer blends and its impact on mechanical and electronic properties. Successful execution of this project could lead to a greener and more sustainable future for organic electronics. The educational objective of the CAREER plan is to build a dynamic polymer program at Purdue University for educating next generation polymer chemists, as well as for raising the public awareness about polymer science and engineering. Specifically, the PI will integrate polymer chemistry and laboratory into undergraduate and graduate curricula, and organize the Notre Dame - Purdue Annual Symposium on Soft Matter and Polymers in collaboration with local high schools. Further, the PI plans to adapt new technological tools (i.e. interactive online Apps that K-12 students and the general public nowadays prefer to interact with) for outreach activities. 


TECHNICAL SUMMARY: 

The CAREER proposal seeks to understand the nature of flow-induced chain alignment and the resulting morphology and its impact on optical, electronic and mechanical properties in melt-processed complementary semiconducting polymer blends (c-SPBs). Flow-induced crystallization has long been an important subject in conventional (insulating) polymer processing, but little is known in a semiconducting polymer melt. In this project, the PI will make melt-processable c-SPBs and study flow-induced structure formation in order to establish the structure-property-processing relationship. In phase I of the project, the PI will synthesize a wide range of semiconducting polymers that can be melted at desired temperatures. Phase II is concerned with elucidating the nature of flow-induced oriented structures and thin-film morphologies in polymer melts by in-situ rheo-optical and rheo-X-ray techniques, among other morphological tools. Phase III is aimed to correlate flow-induced morphologies with their electronic and mechanical properties in aligned fibers or thin films of polymer blends. This project aims to:  1) rationalize the molecular design principles for melt-processable semiconducting polymers,  2) reveal the role of flow-induced crystallization in polymer thin-film morphology development, and  3) offer a fundamental correlation between flow-induced morphologies and important materials properties. The long-term goal of this project is to develop high-performance melt-processable c-SPBs and enable melt-processing of semiconducting polymers for future organic electronics, complementary to or advantageous over current solution-processed approaches.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The CAREER project aims to understand the influence of chain alighment in melt-processed semiconducting polymer blends and exlore charge transport behaviors in polymer-based field-effect transistors. 


When it comes to intellectural merit, it is described as below.
Organic semiconductors have gained enormous attention as an alternative or replacement for conventional inorganic semiconductors. Solution processing has been a primary technology for thin film formation in organic electronics, presumably because it can potentially deliver low cost, fast roll-to-roll printing processing. However, there are many issues that are undermining the notion of solution processing as a viable technology for large scale manufacturing, such as the use of toxic and environmentally-harmful chlorinated solvents, the composition instability of organic semiconductor solutions, the formation of kinetically trapped morphologies and the profound impact of organic solvent residue in thin films, among others. Melt processing involves a reversible liquefaction-solidification process. It is broadly used in industry to produce plastic thin films. Arguably, melt processing is free from all the drawbacks previously mentioned for solution processing, yet the major benefits (i.e. low cost and fast roll-to-roll printing) remain. The employment of melt processing for organic electronics is, however, complicated by the fact that most high performance semiconducting polymers, if not all, will either breakdown before melting or have melting temperatures that are too high for practical use (i.e. > 250 °C). In this project, we addressed the design and synthesis of polymers that can be melt at desired temperatures without sacrificing the integrity of electronic properties We learned the influece of fluid dynamics and crystallization kinetics in these semiconducting polymer melts.In this project, we have gained knowledge on the following aspects:1. Understand the influence of side chains and their combinations on melt-processability
2. Understand the role of conjugation break-spacer on phase transistors and their impact on charge transport
3. Understand the role of rigid amorphous glass transition temperatures in semiconducting polymers
4. Achieve melt-processable semiconducting polymers that exhibit charge carrier mobility beyond 1 cm2/vs5. Demonstrate continuous melt-extrusion of semiconducting polymers with controlled diameters.

When it comes to broader impact, the project has facilited the students development and technology development in high tempearture electronics.
a) Dr. Aristide Gumyusenge, who was previously supported by the CAREER project, will start his independent career in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at MIT in the Spring of 2022.  He won the MRS Graduate Student Gold Award. This award honors and encourages graduate students whose academic achievements and current materials research display a high level of excellence and distinction.  Aristide was also recognized as the Arthur Nowick Graduate Student Awardee for his particular promise as a future teacher and mentor. This award honors the late Dr. Arthur Nowick and his lifelong commitment to teaching and mentoring students in materials science.
b) Dr. William McNutt who had been supported by this project graduated in the April of 2020, with his thesis title of Understand the Effect of Conjugation Break Spacers on Sturture-Property Relationahsip in Partially Conjugated Semiconducting Polymers and Their Thin Films. He is now a Research Scientist at DuPont. 
c) Natalie M Kadlubowski, an undergraduate researcher in the group since the Spring of 2017, was recognized as a 2019 Goldwater Scholar. Natalie has worked on the synthesis of organic semiconductors with graduate student Xuyi Luo.  So far she has co-authored two articles, supported by the CAREER project. The Barry Goldwater Scholarship and Excellence in Education Foundation was established by Congress in 1986 to serve as a living memorial to honor the lifetime work of Senator Barry Goldwater, who served his country for 56 years as a soldier and statesman, including 30 years in the U.S. Senate.f) John Putziger, an undergraduate researcher in the group since the Fall of 2018, was recognized as a 2021 Astronaut Scholar. He is now a graduate student in Chemistry at Cornell University. 
d) We also host an undergradue student, Maria Fernanda Lizarazo Rojas from Universidad Nacional de Colombia, which is part of the UREP-C program. This is the part we proposed in the Education and Outreach program in the CAREER proposal. Maria spent six months with us and worked on the CAREER project. h) As part of the educational component, the PI co-organized the Notre Dame-Purdue Symposium on Soft Matter & Polymers and Poster Session four times.  This one-day symposium usually attracted more 120 registered participants a dozen of invited speakers and more than 50 contributed student poster presentations from University of Notre Dame, Purdue University and our neighboring schools. It addressed a wide variety of topics from the general synthesis, characterization of synthetic soft materials, to their broad applications. Eight poster awards were given to student presenters, including undergraduate, graduate and postdoc fellows.


Last Modified: 10/30/2022
Modified by: Jianguo Mei

Image
  • High temperature semiconducting polymers are used for the preparation of electronics that can survive at elevated temperature
    Aristide Gumyusenge
    Public Domain
    Jianguo Mei
    High Temperature Organic Semiconductors
